cleaned_text: | | Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) Classification & external resources | | | The Red ribbon is a symbol for solidarity with HIV-positive people and those living with AIDS. | | |[ICD](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/ICD.html)-10 | B24. | | |[ICD](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/ICD.html)-9 | 042 emerg/253 | | |[MeSH](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Medical_Subject_Headings.html) | D000163 | Acquired immune deficiency syndrome or acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS or Aids) is a [collection of symptoms and infections](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Syndrome.html) resulting from the specific damage to the [immune system](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Immune_system.html) caused by the [human immunodeficiency virus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/HIV.html) (HIV) in humans, [[1]](#_note-0/) and similar viruses in other species ( [SIV](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Simian_immunodeficiency_virus.html), FIV, etc.). The late stage of the condition leaves individuals susceptible to opportunistic infections and [tumors](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Tumor.html). Although treatments for AIDS and HIV exist to decelerate the [virus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Virus.html)'s progression, there is currently no known cure. HIV, et al., are [transmitted](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Transmission_%28medicine%29.html) through direct contact of a mucous membrane or the bloodstream with a [bodily fluid](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Bodily_fluid.html) containing HIV, such in the form of anal, [vaginal](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Vaginal_sex.html) or oral [sex](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Sexual_intercourse.html), blood transfusion, contaminated [hypodermic needles](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Hypodermic_needle.html), exchange between mother and baby during [pregnancy](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Pregnancy.html), childbirth, or breastfeeding, or other exposure to one of the above bodily fluids. Most researchers believe that HIV originated in sub-Saharan Africa during the twentieth century; [[4]](#_note-Gao/) it is now a pandemic, with an estimated 33.2 million people now living with the disease worldwide. [[5]](#_note-UNAIDS2007/) As of January 2006, the [Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Joint_United_Nations_Programme_on_HIV/AIDS.html) (UNAIDS) and the [World Health Organization](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/World_Health_Organization.html) (WHO) estimate that AIDS has killed more than 25 million people since it was first recognized on June 5, 1981, making it one of the most destructive [epidemics](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Epidemic.html) in recorded history. In 2005 alone, AIDS claimed an estimated 2.4-3.3 million lives, of which more than 570,000 were children. [[6]](#_note-UNAIDS2006/) A third of these deaths are occurring in sub-Saharan Africa, retarding economic growth and destroying human capital. [Antiretroviral](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Antiretroviral_drug.html) treatment reduces both the [mortality](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Mortality_rate.html) and the [morbidity](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Morbidity.html) of HIV infection, but routine access to antiretroviral medication is not available in all countries. [[7]](#_note-Palella/) HIV/AIDS stigma is more severe than that associated with other life-threatening conditions and extends beyond the disease itself to providers and even volunteers involved with the care of people living with HIV. Additional recommended knowledge Infection by HIV For more details on this topic, see [HIV](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/HIV.html). AIDS is the most severe acceleration of [infection](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Infection.html) with HIV. HIV is a [retrovirus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Retrovirus.html) that primarily infects vital organs of the human [immune system](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Immune_system.html) such indirectly destroys CD4+ T cells. [[8]](#_note-Alimonti/) CD4+ T cells are required for the proper functioning of the immune system. When HIV kills CD4+ T cells so that there are fewer than 200 CD4+ T cells per microliter (µL) of [blood](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Blood.html), cellular immunity is lost. In some countries, such as the United States, this leads to a diagnosis of AIDS. In other jurisdictions, such as in Canada, AIDS is only diagnosed when a person infected with HIV is diagnosed with one or more of several AIDS-related opportunistic infections or cancers [[9]](#_note-1/) [[10]](#_note-2/) [[11]](#_note-3/). [Acute](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Acute_%28medical%29.html) HIV infection progresses over time to clinical latent HIV infection and then to early symptomatic HIV infection and later to AIDS, which is identified either on the basis of the amount of CD4+ T cells in the blood, and/or the presence of certain infections, as noted above. In the absence of antiretroviral therapy, the median [time of progression from HIV infection to AIDS](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/HIV_Disease_Progression_Rates.html) is nine to ten years, and the median survival time after developing AIDS is only 9.2 months. [[12]](#_note-Morgan2/) However, the rate of clinical disease progression varies widely between individuals, from two weeks up to 20 years. Many factors affect the rate of progression. These include factors that influence the body's ability to defend against HIV such as the infected person's general immune function. [[13]](#_note-Clerici/) [[14]](#_note-Morgan/) Older people have weaker immune systems, and therefore have a greater risk of rapid disease progression than younger people. Poor access to health care and the existence of coexisting infections such as [tuberculosis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Tuberculosis.html) also may predispose people to faster disease progression. [[12]](#_note-Morgan2/) [[15]](#_note-Gendelman/) [[16]](#_note-Bentwich/) The infected person's [genetic inheritance](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Genetics.html) plays an important role and some people are resistant to certain strains of HIV. An example of this is people with the CCR5-32 mutation are resistant to infection with certain [strains](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Strain_%28biology%29.html) of HIV. [[17]](#_note-Tang/) HIV is genetically variable and exists as different strains, which cause different rates of clinical disease progression. [[18]](#_note-Quinones/) [[19]](#_note-Campbell/) [[20]](#_note-Kaleebu/) The use of highly active antiretroviral therapy prolongs both the median time of progression to AIDS and the median survival time. Diagnosis Since June 5, 1981, many definitions have been developed for [epidemiological](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Epidemiology.html) surveillance such as the [Bangui definition](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Bangui_definition.html) and the [1994 expanded World Health Organization AIDS case definition](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/1994_expanded_World_Health_Organization_AIDS_case_definition.html). However, clinical staging of patients was not an intended use for these systems as they are neither sensitive, nor specific. In developing countries, the [World Health Organization](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/World_Health_Organization.html) staging system for HIV infection and disease, using clinical and laboratory data, is used and in developed countries, the [Centers for Disease Control](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention.html) (CDC) Classification System is used. WHO disease staging system for HIV infection and disease - In 1990, the [World Health Organization](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/World_Health_Organization.html) (WHO) grouped these infections and conditions together by introducing a staging system for patients infected with HIV-1. [[21]](#_note-WHO/) An update took place in September 2005. Most of these conditions are opportunistic infections that are easily treatable in healthy people. - Stage I: HIV infection is asymptomatic and not categorized as AIDS - Stage II: includes minor mucocutaneous manifestations and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections - Stage III: includes unexplained chronic [diarrhea](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Diarrhea.html) for longer than a month, severe bacterial infections and [pulmonary](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Pulmonary.html) tuberculosis - Stage IV: includes toxoplasmosis of [lungs](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lung.html) and [Kaposi's sarcoma](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Kaposi%27s_sarcoma.html); these diseases are indicators of AIDS. CDC classification system for HIV infection Main article: CDC Classification System for HIV Infection In the beginning, the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention.html) (CDC) did not have an official name for the disease, often referring to it by way of the diseases that were associated with it, for example, [lymphadenopathy](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lymphadenopathy.html), the disease after which the discoverers of HIV originally named the virus. [[22]](#_note-MMWR1982a/) [[23]](#_note-Barre/) They also used Kaposi's Sarcoma and Opportunistic Infections, the name by which a task force had been set up in 1981. [[24]](#_note-MMWR1982b/) In the general press, the term GRID, which stood for [Gay-Related Immune Deficiency](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Gay-Related_Immune_Deficiency.html), had been coined. [[25]](#_note-Altman/) However, after determining that AIDS was not isolated to the homosexual community, [[24]](#_note-MMWR1982b/) the term GRID became misleading and AIDS was introduced at a meeting in July 1982. [[26]](#_note-Kher/) By September 1982 the CDC started using the name AIDS, and properly defined the illness. [[27]](#_note-MMWR1982c/) In 1993, the CDC expanded their definition of AIDS to include all HIV positive people with a CD4+ T cell count below 200 per µL of blood or 14% of all [lymphocytes](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lymphocyte.html). [[28]](#_note-MMWR/) The majority of new AIDS cases in developed countries use either this definition or the pre-1993 CDC definition. The AIDS diagnosis still stands even if, after treatment, the CD4+ T cell count rises to above 200 per µL of blood or other AIDS-defining illnesses are cured. HIV test - Many people are unaware that they are infected with HIV. [[29]](#_note-Kumaranayake/) Less than 1% of the sexually active urban population in Africa has been tested, and this proportion is even lower in rural populations. Furthermore, only 0.5% of pregnant women attending urban health facilities are counseled, tested or receive their test results. Again, this proportion is even lower in rural health facilities. [[29]](#_note-Kumaranayake/) Therefore, [donor blood](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Donor_blood.html) and blood products used in medicine and medical research are screened for HIV. Typical HIV tests, including the HIV [enzyme](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Enzyme.html) [immunoassay](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Immunoassay.html) and the [Western blot](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Western_blot.html) assay, detect HIV [antibodies](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Antibody.html) [serum](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Blood_plasma.html), [plasma](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Blood_plasma.html), oral fluid, dried blood spot or [urine](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Urine.html) of patients. However, the window period (the time between initial infection and the development of detectable antibodies against the infection) can vary. This is why it can take 3-6 months to [seroconvert](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Seroconversion.html) and test positive. Commercially available tests to detect other HIV antigens, HIV- [RNA](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/RNA.html), and HIV- [DNA](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/DNA.html) in order to detect HIV infection prior to the development of detectable antibodies are available. For the diagnosis of HIV infection these [assays](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Assay.html) are not specifically approved, but are nonetheless routinely used in developed countries. Symptoms and complications The symptoms of AIDS are primarily the result of conditions that do not normally develop in individuals with healthy [immune systems](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Immune_system.html). Most of these conditions are infections caused by [bacteria](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Bacteria.html), [viruses](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Virus.html), [fungi](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Fungus.html) and [parasites](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Parasite.html) that are normally controlled by the elements of the immune system that HIV damages. Opportunistic infections are common in people with AIDS. [[30]](#_note-Holmes/) HIV affects nearly every organ system. People with AIDS also have an increased risk of developing various cancers such as [Kaposi's sarcoma](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Kaposi%27s_sarcoma.html), cervical cancer and cancers of the immune system known as [lymphomas](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lymphoma.html). Additionally, people with AIDS often have systemic symptoms of infection like [fevers](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Fever.html), [sweats](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Sweat.html) (particularly at night), swollen glands, chills, weakness, and [weight loss](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Weight_loss.html). [[31]](#_note-Guss/) [[32]](#_note-Guss2/) After the diagnosis of AIDS is made, the current average survival time with antiretroviral therapy (as of 2005) is estimated to be more than 5 years, [[33]](#_note-Schneider/) but because new treatments continue to be developed and because HIV continues to evolve resistance to treatments, estimates of survival time are likely to continue to change. Without antiretroviral therapy, death normally occurs within a year. [[12]](#_note-Morgan2/) Most patients die from opportunistic infections or malignancies associated with the progressive failure of the immune system. [[34]](#_note-Lawn/) The rate of clinical disease progression varies widely between individuals and has been shown to be affected by many factors such as host susceptibility and immune function [[13]](#_note-Clerici/) [[14]](#_note-Morgan/) [[17]](#_note-Tang/) health care and co-infections, [[12]](#_note-Morgan2/) [[34]](#_note-Lawn/) as well as factors relating to the viral strain. [[19]](#_note-Campbell/) [[35]](#_note-Campbell2/) [[36]](#_note-Senkaali/) The specific opportunistic infections that AIDS patients develop depend in part on the prevalence of these infections in the geographic area in which the patient lives. Major pulmonary illnesses [Pneumocystis pneumonia](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Pneumocystis_pneumonia_%28PCP%29.html) (originally known as Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, and still abbreviated as PCP, which now stands for Pneumocystis pneumonia) is relatively rare in healthy, immunocompetent people, but common among HIV-infected individuals. It is caused by [Pneumocystis jirovecii](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Pneumocystis_pneumonia_%28PCP%29.html). Before the advent of effective diagnosis, treatment and routine [prophylaxis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Prophylaxis.html) in Western countries, it was a common immediate cause of death. In developing countries, it is still one of the first indications of AIDS in untested individuals, although it does not generally occur unless the CD4 count is less than 200 per µL. [[37]](#_note-Feldman/) [Tuberculosis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Tuberculosis.html) (TB) is unique among infections associated with HIV because it is transmissible to immunocompetent people via the respiratory route, is easily treatable once identified, may occur in early-stage HIV disease, and is preventable with drug therapy. However, [multidrug resistance](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Multidrug_resistance.html) is a potentially serious problem. Even though its incidence has declined because of the use of directly observed therapy and other improved practices in Western countries, this is not the case in developing countries where HIV is most prevalent. In early-stage HIV infection (CD4 count >300 cells per µL), TB typically presents as a pulmonary disease. In advanced HIV infection, TB often presents atypically with extrapulmonary (systemic) disease a common feature. Symptoms are usually constitutional and are not localized to one particular site, often affecting [bone nervous system](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Central_nervous_system.html). [[38]](#_note-Decker/) Alternatively, symptoms may relate more to the site of extrapulmonary involvement. Major gastro-intestinal illnesses - Esophagitis is an inflammation of the lining of the lower end of the [esophagus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Esophagus.html) (gullet or swallowing tube leading to the [stomach](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Stomach.html)). In HIV infected individuals, this is normally due to fungal ( [candidiasis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Candidiasis.html)) or viral ( [herpes simplex-1](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Herpes_simplex_virus.html) or [cytomegalovirus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Cytomegalovirus.html)) infections. In rare cases, it could be due to [mycobacteria](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Mycobacteria.html). [[39]](#_note-Zaidi/) - Unexplained chronic [diarrhea](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Diarrhea.html) in HIV infection is due to many possible causes, including common bacterial ( avium](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Mycobacterium_avium.html) complex (MAC) and [cytomegalovirus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Cytomegalovirus.html) (CMV) [colitis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Colitis.html). In some cases, diarrhea may be a side effect of several drugs used to treat HIV, or it may simply accompany HIV infection, particularly during primary HIV infection. It may also be a side effect of [antibiotics](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Antibiotic.html) used to treat bacterial causes of diarrhea (common for [Clostridium difficile](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Clostridium_difficile.html)). In the later stages of HIV infection, diarrhea is thought to be a reflection of changes in the way the [intestinal tract](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Intestinal_tract.html) absorbs nutrients, and may be an important component of HIV-related [wasting](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Wasting.html). [[40]](#_note-Guerrant/) Major neurological illnesses - Toxoplasmosis is a disease caused by the single-celled [parasite](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Parasite.html) called Toxoplasma gondii; it usually infects the brain causing toxoplasma [encephalitis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Encephalitis.html) but it can infect and cause disease in the [eyes](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Eye.html) and lungs. [[41]](#_note-Luft/) [Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Progressive_multifocal_leukoencephalopathy.html) (PML) is a demyelinating disease, in which the gradual destruction of the [myelin](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Myelin.html) sheath covering the axons of nerve cells impairs the transmission of nerve impulses. It is caused by a virus called [JC virus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/JC_virus.html) which occurs in 70% of the population in [latent](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Virus_latency.html) form, causing disease only when the immune system has been severely weakened, as is the case for AIDS patients. It progresses rapidly, usually causing death within months of diagnosis. [[42]](#_note-Sadler/) [AIDS dementia complex](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/AIDS_dementia_complex.html) (ADC) is a metabolic [encephalopathy](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Encephalopathy.html) induced by HIV infection and fueled by immune activation of HIV infected brain [macrophages](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Macrophage.html) and [microglia](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Microglia.html) which secrete [neurotoxins](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Neurotoxin.html) of both host and viral origin. [[43]](#_note-Gray/) Specific neurological impairments are manifested by cognitive, behavioral, and motor abnormalities that occur after years of HIV infection and is associated with low CD4+ T cell levels and high plasma viral loads. Prevalence is 10-20% in Western countries [[44]](#_note-Grant/) but only 1-2% of HIV infections in India. [[45]](#_note-Satischandra/) [[46]](#_note-Wadia/) This difference is possibly due to the HIV subtype in India. - Cryptococcal meningitis is an infection of the [meninx](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Meninges.html) (the membrane covering the brain and [spinal cord](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Spinal_cord.html)) by the fungus Cryptococcus [fatigue](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Fatigue_%28physical%29.html), Patients may also develop [seizures](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Seizure.html) and confusion; left untreated, it can be lethal. Major HIV-associated malignancies Patients with HIV infection have substantially increased incidence of several malignant [cancers](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Cancer.html). This is primarily due to co-infection with an The following confer a diagnosis of AIDS when they occur in an HIV-infected person. - Kaposi's sarcoma (KS) is the most common tumor in HIV-infected patients. The appearance of this tumor in young homosexual men in 1981 was one of the first signals of the AIDS epidemic. Caused by a gammaherpes virus called [Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpes virus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Kaposi%27s_sarcoma-associated_herpes_virus.html) (KSHV), it often appears as purplish nodules on the skin, but can affect other organs, especially the mouth, gastrointestinal tract, and lungs. - nervous system lymphoma](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Primary_central_nervous_system_lymphoma.html) present more often in HIV-infected patients. These particular cancers often foreshadow a poor prognosis. In some cases these lymphomas are AIDS-defining. [Epstein-Barr virus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Epstein-Barr_virus.html) (EBV) or KSHV cause many of these lymphomas. - Cervical cancer in HIV-infected women is considered AIDS-defining. It is caused by [human papillomavirus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Human_papillomavirus.html) (HPV). In addition to the AIDS-defining tumors listed above, HIV-infected patients are at increased risk of certain other tumors, such as [Hodgkin's disease](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Hodgkin%27s_disease.html) and [anal](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Anal_carcinoma.html) and [rectal carcinomas](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Rectal_carcinoma.html). However, the incidence of many common tumors, such as breast cancer or colon cancer, does not increase in HIV-infected patients. In areas where [HAART](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/HAART.html) is extensively used to treat AIDS, the incidence of many AIDS-related malignancies has decreased, but at the same time malignant cancers overall have become the most common cause of death of HIV-infected patients. [[49]](#_note-Bonnet/) Other opportunistic infections AIDS patients often develop opportunistic infections that present with non-specific symptoms, especially low-grade fevers and weight loss. These include infection with [Mycobacterium avium](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Mycobacterium_avium.html)-intracellulare and [cytomegalovirus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Cytomegalovirus.html) (CMV). CMV can cause colitis, as described above, and CMV retinitis can cause blindness. [Penicilliosis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Penicilliosis.html) due to [Penicillium marneffei](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Penicillium_marneffei.html) is now the third most common opportunistic infection (after extrapulmonary tuberculosis and [cryptococcosis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Cryptococcosis.html)) in HIV-positive individuals within the endemic area of Southeast Asia. [[50]](#_note-Skoulidis/) Transmission and prevention Estimated per act risk for acquisition of HIV by exposure route [[51]](#_note-MMWR3/) | Exposure Route || Estimated infections| per 10,000 exposures to an infected source | Blood Transfusion || 9,000|[[52]](#_note-Donegan/) | Childbirth || 2,500|[[53]](#_note-Coovadia/) || 0.5|[[56]](#_note-Varghese/)§ | * assuming no condom use § source refers to oral intercourse| performed on a man The three main transmission routes of HIV are sexual contact, exposure to infected body fluids or tissues, and from mother to [fetus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Fetus.html) or child during perinatal period. It is possible to find HIV in the [saliva](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Saliva.html), [tears](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Tears.html), and [urine](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Urine.html) of infected individuals, but there are no recorded cases of infection by these secretions, and the risk of infection is negligible. [[59]](#_note-4/) Sexual contact The majority of HIV infections are acquired through unprotected sexual relations between partners, one of whom has HIV. Heterosexual intercourse is the primary mode of HIV infection worldwide. [[60]](#_note-5/) Sexual transmission occurs with the contact between sexual secretions of one partner with the rectal, genital or oral mucous membranes of another. Unprotected receptive sexual acts are riskier than unprotected insertive sexual acts, with the risk for transmitting HIV from an infected partner to an uninfected partner through unprotected anal intercourse greater than the risk for transmission through vaginal intercourse or oral sex. Oral sex is not without its risks as HIV is transmissible through both insertive and receptive oral sex. [[61]](#_note-Rothenberg/) The risk of HIV transmission from exposure to [saliva](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Saliva.html) is considerably smaller than the risk from exposure to semen; contrary to popular belief, one would have to swallow gallons of saliva from a carrier to run a significant risk of becoming infected. [[62]](#_note-Vincenzi/) Approximately 30% of women in ten countries representing "diverse cultural, geographical and urban/rural settings" report that their first sexual experience was forced or coerced, making sexual violence a key driver of the HIV/AIDS pandemic. [[63]](#_note-vaw/) Sexual assault greatly increases the risk of HIV transmission as protection is rarely employed and physical trauma to the vaginal cavity frequently occurs which facilitates the transmission of HIV. [[64]](#_note-Koenig/) Sexually transmitted infections (STI) increase the risk of HIV transmission and infection because they cause the disruption of the normal epithelial barrier by genital ulceration and/or microulceration; and by accumulation of pools of HIV-susceptible or HIV-infected cells ( [lymphocytes](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lymphocyte.html) and [macrophages](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Macrophage.html)) in semen and vaginal secretions. Epidemiological studies from sub-Saharan Africa, Europe and North America have suggested that there is approximately a four times greater risk of becoming infected with HIV in the presence of a genital ulcer such as those caused by [syphilis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Syphilis.html) and/or [chancroid](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Chancroid.html). There is also a significant though lesser increased risk in the presence of STIs such as [gonorrhea](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Gonorrhea.html), [Chlamydial infection](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Chlamydia_infection.html) and accumulations of lymphocytes and macrophages. [[128]](#_note-Herek1999/) [[130]](#_note-Herek2002/) [[131]](#_note-Herek2005/) - For more details on this topic, see Stigma and HIV-AIDS, A review of the literature [[132]](#_note-HRSA/) Origin of HIV Main article: [AIDS origin](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/AIDS_origin.html) AIDS was first reported June 5, 1981, when the U.S. [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention.html) recorded a cluster of [Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Pneumocystis_pneumonia_%28PCP%29.html) (now still classified as PCP but known to be caused by [Pneumocystis jirovecii](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Pneumocystis_pneumonia_%28PCP%29.html)) in five homosexual men in Los Angeles. [[133]](#_note-MMWR2/) Three of the earliest known instances of HIV infection are: - A plasma sample taken in 1959 from an adult male living in Kinshasa, today part of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. [[134]](#_note-Zhu/) - HIV found in tissue samples from "Robert R.", a 15 year old African-American teenager who died in St. Louis in 1969. [[135]](#_note-Kolata/) - HIV found in tissue samples from Arvid Noe, a Norwegian sailor who died around 1976. [[136]](#_note-HooperBMJ/) Two species of HIV infect humans: [HIV-1](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/HIV-1.html) and [HIV-2](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/HIV-2.html). HIV-1 is more virulent and more easily transmitted. HIV-1 is the source of the majority of HIV infections throughout the world, while HIV-2 is not as easily transmitted and is largely confined to West Africa. [[137]](#_note-Reeves/) Both HIV-1 and HIV-2 are of primate origin. The origin of HIV-1 is the Central Common Chimpanzee (Pan troglodytes troglodytes) found in southern Cameroon. [[138]](#_note-Keele/) It is HIV-2 originated from the Sooty Mangabey (Cercocebus atys), an Old World monkey of Guinea Bissau, Gabon, and Cameroon. Most experts believe that HIV probably transferred to humans as a result of direct contact with primates, for instance during hunting or butchery. [[139]](#_note-CohenOrigns/) A more controversial theory known as the [OPV AIDS hypothesis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/OPV_AIDS_hypothesis.html) suggests that the AIDS epidemic was inadvertently started in the late 1950s in the Belgian Congo by [Hilary Koprowski](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Hilary_Koprowski.html)'s research into a [polio](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Polio.html) [vaccine](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Vaccine.html). [[140]](#_note-Curtis/) [[141]](#_note-Hooper/) According to scientific consensus, this scenario is not supported by the available evidence. [[142]](#_note-refuted/) [[143]](#_note-Berry/) [[144]](#_note-VaccineQA/) A 2007 study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences by Michael Worobey and Dr. Arthur Pitchenik claimed that, based on the results of genetic analysis, HIV probably moved from Africa to Haiti and then entered the United States around 1969. [[145]](#_note-9/) Alternative hypotheses - A small minority of scientists and activists question the connection between HIV and AIDS, [[146]](#_note-Duesberg/) the existence of HIV itself, [[147]](#_note-Papadopulos/) or the validity of current testing and treatment methods. Though these claims have been examined and widely rejected by the scientific community, [[148]](#_note-consensus/) they have had a significant political impact, particularly in South Africa, where governmental acceptance of AIDS denialism has been blamed for an ineffective response to that country's AIDS epidemic. [[149]](#_note-10/) [[150]](#_note-11/) [[151]](#_note-12/) HIV and AIDS misconceptions - A number of misconceptions have arisen surrounding HIV/AIDS. Three of the most common are that AIDS can spread through casual contact, that sexual intercourse with a virgin will cure AIDS, and that HIV can infect only homosexual men and drug users. Other misconceptions are that any act of anal intercourse between gay men can lead to AIDS infection, and that open discussion of homosexuality and HIV in schools will lead to increased rates of homosexuality and AIDS.
